sample_mentions.author: investor_mike
sample_mentions.source_text: Can someone explain DSCR loans? I keep hearing about them but don't understand how they work. Do I need to show W2 income? My rental has great cash flow but my personal income isn't that high. Looking to buy more properties without the traditional mortgage hassle.

sample_mentions.author: realestate_pro
sample_mentions.source_text: DSCR loans are a game changer. Just closed on 3 properties using them. The lender only cares about the property's income, not mine. Calculate your net operating income and divide by your annual debt payment. If it's above 1.25, you're usually good. Closed in 21 days vs 45+ for conventional.

sample_mentions.author: Sarah Thompson
sample_mentions.source_text: After analyzing 500+ deals this year, I can confirm: off-market deals consistently offer the best margins. Our direct mail campaign to absentee owners in Houston suburbs yielded 0.8% response rate and 12 closed deals at 14% below market. The key is targeting the right lists and persistent follow-up.

sample_mentions.author: passive_lp_investor
sample_mentions.source_text: Question for experienced LPs: How do you evaluate syndication sponsors? I have $500k to deploy and getting pitched constantly. What should I look for in terms of track record, fee structure, and tax efficiency? Also concerned about alignment of interests.

sample_mentions.author: @realestate_cpa
sample_mentions.source_text: PSA for passive investors: Don't overlook cost segregation in your syndication deals. A proper study can accelerate 30-40% of the building value into 5-7 year classes. On a $10M property, that's $3-4M in accelerated depreciation. Huge tax benefit in year 1.

sample_mentions.author: Marcus Johnson
sample_mentions.source_text: Contrarian take: Houston multifamily is a better play than Austin right now. Everyone's chasing Austin, but Houston has better fundamentals - lower vacancy (5.8% vs 7.2%), stronger job growth, and cap rates are 50-75 bps higher. Just closed a 150-unit deal in Pearland at 5.8% cap. Would've been 5.0% in Austin.
